description: Medium - Detailed Analysis and Systemic Understanding

questions.question: What advantages did the Macedonian phalanx have compared to Roman legions? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Devastating in open field battles with long spears and tight formation
Superior training and discipline
Better adaptability to terrain and unexpected situations
More effective cavalry coordination
Rigid formation meant less flexibility on broken ground
Capable of fighting effectively in any environment

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describe the Hellenistic world that Rome was entering in the 3rd century BCE? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: It was dominated by three major kingdoms: Ptolemaic Egypt, Seleucid Empire, and Macedonia
It was characterized by balance of power with no single dominant force
It contained numerous smaller kingdoms and city-states competing for influence
Rome was already the dominant power when the period began
The three major kingdoms were all economically equal and militarily matched
Hellenistic culture blended Greek, Persian, Egyptian and other influences
questions.text_reference: Section 1 - Macedonia Under Philip V: An Eastern Superpower

questions.question: What were the main military restrictions placed on Carthage by the Treaty of 201 BCE? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Carthage had to provide all military forces to Rome on demand
Carthage could maintain only a small navy
Carthage could maintain only a limited standing army
Carthage was forbidden from wars of conquest
Carthage could only wage defensive wars with Roman approval
Carthage was allowed to rebuild its military after 20 years

questions.question: What challenges did Carthage's economic recovery create for Rome's strategic planning?
options: Roman leadership feared Carthage would eventually become a threat again
Rome was unconcerned about Carthage's economic status
Carthage's recovery proved the treaty terms were insufficient
Carthage's prosperity might fund military rebuilding
A peaceful, prosperous Carthage was more dangerous than a desperate one
Carthaginian merchants were competing in trade throughout the Mediterranean

questions.question: Which of the following were consequences of Rome's military victories over the major Hellenistic powers? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome became the unchallenged military superpower of the Mediterranean
Rome had to develop new systems of empire administration
Wealth from conquered territories began reshaping Roman society
Roman military superiority was proven against all rivals
The Hellenistic kingdoms immediately united against Rome
Rome's internal politics became destabilized by competition for provincial control
questions.text_reference: Section 10 - The Overall Picture: Rome Unchallenged

questions.question: What was the strategic significance of Rome's ability to conduct simultaneous warfare during the First Macedonian War? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: It proved Rome could defeat any opponent militarily
It demonstrated Rome's exceptional institutional capacity and resource organization
It revealed that most ancient powers could not manage multiple theaters of war
It showed Rome was weaker than previously thought, needing to divide forces
It allowed Rome to easily conquer Macedonia while fighting Hannibal
It set the pattern for Rome's future Mediterranean dominance

questions.question: Which statements accurately describe the Battle of Cynoscephalae? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: It was fought between Roman legions and Macedonian phalanx forces
Roman forces exploited terrain to outmaneuver the rigid phalanx formation
The battle proved the Roman legionary system was superior to the phalanx
Macedonian casualties were massive
The Macedonian phalanx proved undefeated in the battle
Rome subsequently showed it could defeat the greatest powers of the Hellenistic world

questions.question: What role did historical memory and trauma play in Rome's decision to destroy Carthage? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome had completely forgotten Hannibal by the Third Punic War
Hannibal's invasion and the destruction of Roman legions left psychological scars
Cato and others invoked the Second Punic War as justification for total destruction
Roman fear of Carthage was rational given the current military balance
The fear persisted even though Carthage had been weakened by treaty
Psychological trauma from war influenced strategic decision-making

questions.question: Which of the following represent ways Rome used diplomacy and alliance alongside military force during this period?
options: Rome conquered all territories by military force alone
Egypt was increasingly drawn into dependence on Rome for security
Rome immediately destroyed all potential rivals without negotiation
Rome maintained alliance with Masinissa to weaken Carthage
Flamininus declared Greek city-states 'free and independent' while maintaining Roman dominance
Rome used envoys to pressure Carthage into treaty violations that justified war

questions.question: What contradictions existed between Rome's declared policies and actual practices toward the Mediterranean during this era?
options: Rome was completely transparent about its imperial ambitions throughout this period
Greece was declared 'free and independent' while being under Roman dominance
Rome maintained alliance with Masinissa while claiming to be neutral about Carthage
Rome claimed to support the balance of power while systematically eliminating rivals
Egypt was nominally independent while actually dependent on Rome for decisions
Rome's public rationales for war sometimes differed from strategic motivations
questions.text_reference: Multiple sections - contradictions between theory and practice
